sentences.english: Come adore, on bended knee, Christ the Lord the newborn King.
sentences.chinese: 屈膝跪拜新生王，救主基督今降生。

sentences.english: I knelt there, ripped up the poem, and threw the pieces of paper into the air, crying (really hard).
sentences.chinese: 我跪拜它，然后撕了它，把碎片洒向空中，大声痛哭。

sentences.english: Cheng's wife put her money on the table, lit joss sticks and kowtowed just like others there.
sentences.chinese: 成名的妻子把钱放在案上，象前边的人一样烧香跪拜。

sentences.english: The amenity of bended, knees, evolving, from tile ancient pose of sitting.
sentences.chinese: 跪拜礼则是由古人的坐姿演化而来。

sentences.english: May nations serve you and peoples bow down to you.
sentences.chinese: 愿多民事奉你，多国跪拜你。

sentences.english: And all the king's servants, that were in the king's gate, bowed, and reverenced Haman: for the king had so commanded concerning him.
sentences.chinese: 在朝门的一切臣仆都跪拜哈曼，因为王如此吩咐。

sentences.english: Many pilgrims knelt piously at the shrine.
sentences.chinese: 许多朝圣者心虔意诚地在神殿跪拜。

sentences.english: As a fine Pu chicken meet cable dolong, that he duolong bow.
sentences.chinese: 假扮溥一的细鸡遇见索多隆，多隆即跪拜他。

sentences.english: Muslims bow to Mecca when they pray.
sentences.chinese: 穆斯林祈祷时向麦加圣地俯身跪拜。

sentences.english: After putting various offerings on the altar table , he kneeled down and began to offer sacrifices to the ancestors.
sentences.chinese: 他在供案上摆放了各种供品，然后开始跪拜祭祀。

sentences.english: Everyday he saw people come to the temple and bow to the statue of the Buddha.
sentences.chinese: 每天，他都看到人们来到寺院，在佛像前跪拜。

sentences.english: They knelt before the image of the Buddha.
Or to my knees will I fall?
Pike-li-li-li can be divided into two kinds of ceremony and prostrated themselves.
sentences.chinese: 屈体礼可分为立礼与跪拜礼两种。

sentences.english: Chow Yun Fat(Zhou Runfa) together with Zhujun performed the ancient prostration ceremony toward the audiences.
sentences.chinese: 朱军和周润发一起向观众行古代跪拜礼？

sentences.english: Wherewith shall I come before the LORD, and bow myself before the high God?
sentences.chinese: 我朝见耶和华，在至高神面前跪拜，当献上什么呢。

definition: to kowtow/also written 磕頭|磕头[ke1 tou2]
to kneel three times and kowtow nine times (formal etiquette on meeting the emperor)
to kowtow (traditional greeting, esp. to a superior, involving kneeling and pressing one's forehead to the ground)/also written 磕頭|磕头[ke1 tou2]
to kowtow (traditional greeting, esp. to a superior, involving kneeling and pressing one's forehead to the ground)
to kneel/to go down on one's knees
to formally call on/to worship (a God)/to pay homage to sb
to bow down low/to make obeisance/to kneel and bow
to kneel down/to sink to one's knees/to grovel
to worship/to make customary deferences to/a pilgrimage
to kneel as in prayer (without sitting back on the heels)
